success_criteria: input element or button is missing an associated label, it contains an alt attribute, or its label is empty

error_fixes.problem_type: Input element or button missing associated label
error_fixes.CoT:
First, let's identify input elements and buttons that are missing an associated label, have an empty label, or have alt attributes. We will focus on the form elements as they are the ones that usually require labels for accessibility. 

Let's start by looking at each input element and button within the form and checking if it meets the criteria mentioned.

success_criteria: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
fixed_example:
<video controls>
<source src="bookstore-video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>

error_fixes.problem_type: Audio or video element should avoid automatically playing audio
error_fixes.offending_line:
<video width="640" height="360" controls>
<source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
error_fixes.fixed_line:
<video width="640" height="360" controls autoplay muted>
<source src="video.mp4" type="video/mp4">
Your browser does not support the video tag.
</video>
error_fixes.CoT:
Step 1: Identify all audio or video elements on the page.
Step 2: Check if any of the video elements have autoplay attribute set.
Step 3: If autoplay is set, determine if the video also includes audio.
Step 4: If any video includes audio and autoplay is set, recommend removing the autoplay attribute to comply with accessibility guidelines.

success_criteria: <b> <i> or <font> tag should not be used

error_fixes.CoT:
1. Identify any <b>, <i>, or <font> tags in the HTML.
2. Remove or replace any instances of these tags with appropriate semantic HTML elements or CSS styles.

success_criteria: onmousedown event missing onkeydown event or script is not keyboard accessible

error_fixes.offending_line: <button type="submit" style="color: rgb(255, 255, 255); background-color: rgb(76, 175, 80);">Search Cars</button>
error_fixes.fixed_line: <button type="submit" style="color: rgb(255, 255, 255); background-color: rgb(76, 175, 80);" onkeydown="if(event.key === 'Enter') { this.click(); }">Search Cars</button>
error_fixes.CoT:
1. Look for elements that have interactive functionality, such as buttons or form inputs, that may be missing keyboard accessibility features.
2. Check if there are any elements that rely solely on mouse events, such as onmousedown, without equivalent keyboard events like onkeydown.
3. Evaluate if any scripts or event handlers are used in a way that could be problematic for keyboard-only users.
4. Pay particular attention to form elements like input fields, buttons, and checkboxes, as these are common areas where keyboard accessibility issues may occur.
5. Identify any areas where users may have difficulty navigating or interacting with the page using only the keyboard.

success_criteria: meta refresh with a time-out is used.

error_fixes.offending_line: <marquee> element should not be used as it is not accessible.
error_fixes.fixed_line: <marquee> element should be removed or replaced with a more accessible alternative.
error_fixes.CoT:
Sure! To find the issue of using the `<marquee>` element, we need to:

1. Identify if the `<marquee>` element is present in the HTML code.
2. If found, determine where it is located and what content is being displayed using `<marquee>`.
3. Confirm that the `<marquee>` element is being used for scrolling text or images, which is not accessible.
4. Provide a recommendation on how to improve accessibility by replacing or removing the `<marquee>` element.

error_fixes.fixed_line: <title>Car Rental Service - Your Trusted Car Rental Provider</title>
error_fixes.CoT: Sure, I will go through the HTML provided and check each `<title>` element for being empty. Let's start by checking the `<title>` element in the `<head>` section of the HTML.

First, I will locate all the anchor elements in the HTML code. Then, I will check each anchor element to see if it contains any text. If an anchor element does not have any text content between the opening and closing tags, then that would be the issue of "anchor element containing no text". Let me start by finding all anchor elements in the code.

success_criteria: document language not identified or incorrect

error_fixes.problem_type: Document language not identified or incorrect
error_fixes.CoT:
Step 1: Identify the language attribute in the html tag.
Step 2: Verify if the value of the language attribute is correct according to the content language used in the document.

success_criteria: input element has more than one associated label

error_fixes.problem_type: input element has more than one associated label
error_fixes.CoT:
Step 1: Identify all the input elements on the form.
Step 2: Find all the labels associated with each input element.
Step 3: Check if any input element has more than one associated label.

success_criteria: element does not have complete start and end tags or id attribute is not unique

error_fixes.problem_type: element does not have complete start and end tags
error_fixes.CoT:
1. We will start by checking if all elements have complete start and end tags.
2. Then we will check if all input elements have unique id attributes.
